title: Clique Definition
content:
A **clique** in a graph G is a set S of vertices where every pair is adjacent.

Formally: ∀ u, v ∈ S, u ≠ v → G.Adj u v

Examples: A triangle {a, b, c} with all edges is a 3-clique.

title: Maximal Clique
content:
A clique is **maximal** if no vertex can be added while maintaining the clique property.

Note: Maximal ≠ maximum! A maximal clique cannot be extended, but may not be the largest clique in the graph.

title: Set of Maximal Cliques
content:
`maximalCliques G` is the set of all maximal cliques in G.

A graph can have exponentially many maximal cliques — the Moon-Moser bound gives 3^(n/3) in the worst case.

title: Clique Transversal
content:
A set T is a **clique transversal** if it intersects every maximal clique.

Formally: ∀ maximal clique C, T ∩ C ≠ ∅

This ensures T 'hits' or 'covers' every maximal clique.

title: Clique Transversal Number τ(G)
content:
**τ(G)** = minimum size of a clique transversal.

This measures how 'spread out' the maximal cliques are. Small τ means cliques are clustered; large τ means they're dispersed.

Computing τ is NP-hard in general.

title: Full Vertex Set is Transversal
content:
The entire vertex set V is always a clique transversal — it trivially intersects every clique.

This gives the trivial bound τ(G) ≤ n.

title: Empty Graph
content:
**Empty graph:** τ(⊥) = n

Every singleton {v} is a maximal clique (no edges to extend). To hit all n singletons, we need all n vertices.

title: Complete Graph
content:
**Complete graph:** τ(⊤) = 1

The entire vertex set is the unique maximal clique. Any single vertex hits it.

title: Erdős-Gallai-Tuza Bound
content:
**The Known Bound:**

τ(G) ≤ n - √(2n) + O(1)

This says we can always find a transversal of size roughly n - √(2n).

The proof uses a clever greedy algorithm.

title: Question 1: ω(n) Improvement
content:
**OPEN:** Can we achieve τ(G) ≤ n - ω(n)√n for some ω(n) → ∞?

This asks: can the constant '1' in front of √n be replaced by a growing function?

Even ω(n) = log log n would be progress!

title: Question 2: √(n log n) Bound
content:
**OPEN:** Is τ(G) ≤ n - c√(n log n) for some constant c > 0?

This is stronger than Question 1 — if true, it would imply Question 1 with ω(n) = c√(log n).

This is connected to triangle-free independence.

title: Independent Set
content:
An **independent set** has no edges between its vertices — the complement of a clique.

In the complement graph Ḡ, independent sets become cliques and vice versa.

title: Triangle-Free Graph
content:
A graph is **triangle-free** if it contains no 3-clique.

Equivalently: no three vertices are pairwise adjacent.

Triangle-free graphs are important because they force large independent sets.

title: Triangle-Free Independence Function
content:
**f(n)** = minimum independence number over all triangle-free graphs on n vertices.

This is the guaranteed size of an independent set in any triangle-free graph.

Kim proved f(n) = Θ(√(n log n)).

title: Erdős-Gallai-Tuza Conjecture
content:
**Conjecture:** τ(G) ≤ n - f(n)

This would connect clique transversal directly to triangle-free independence.

Since f(n) = Θ(√(n log n)), this would answer Question 2!

title: Kim's Theorem
content:
**Kim (1995):** f(n) = Θ(√(n log n))

The lower bound comes from a probabilistic construction.
The upper bound from Ramsey theory: R(3, k) ≥ ck²/log k.

This is the triangle-free Ramsey problem.

title: Conjecture Implies Question 2
content:
If ErdősGallaiTuzaConjecture is true, then Question2_LogImprovement follows.

Proof: τ ≤ n - f(n) and f(n) ≥ c√(n log n) give τ ≤ n - c√(n log n).

title: Near-Tight Constructions
content:
**The bound is nearly optimal:**

There exist graphs with τ(G) ≈ n - √(2n).

So the question is whether the multiplicative constant can be improved, not the √n exponent.

title: Clique Cover Duality
content:
**Clique cover number** = minimum cliques needed to cover all vertices.

**Relation:** τ(G) ≥ clique cover number

This is because a transversal must include at least one vertex from each covering clique.

title: Main Result
content:
**Erdős Problem #610: OPEN**

Known: τ(G) ≤ n - √(2n) + O(1)

Open:
1. Can we improve to n - ω(n)√n for ω → ∞?
2. Can we achieve n - c√(n log n)?

The conjecture τ ≤ n - f(n) would resolve Question 2.
